neutron/cmd/upgrade_checks/checks.py.message: You need to add new check to that list too

1) Why counting a column you didn't request in the query? This should not work. It could if the count() is in the query itself
2) This should be just func.count(), to count the number of registers matching this query and the group_by filter.
Why "> 2"? We need to find all queries "> 1", right?

Exactly, we group by the three fields, then look at all groups that we have found more than one segment for. I don't think it matters much if we count the NetworkSegment.id or * in this case. I've tried out both queries in my qa landscape. For comparison, here's the SQL for them, starting from query = query.group_by(...):

>>> print(query.having(func.count() > 1))
SELECT networksegments.network_id AS networksegments_network_id 
FROM networksegments 
WHERE networksegments.physical_network IS NOT NULL GROUP BY networksegments.network_id, networksegments.network_type, networksegments.physical_network 
HAVING count(*) > %(count_1)s

>>> print(query.having(func.count(segment.NetworkSegment.id) > 1))
SELECT networksegments.network_id AS networksegments_network_id 
FROM networksegments 
WHERE networksegments.physical_network IS NOT NULL GROUP BY networksegments.network_id, networksegments.network_type, networksegments.physical_network 
HAVING count(networksegments.id) > %(count_1)s

For patchset 11 I've adopted your first recommendation, but I can switch back to segment.NetworkSegment.id, as both should work.

Actually no because the network_id could be repeated. This should be:

    query = ctx.session.query(segment.NetworkSegment.network_id,
                              func.count(segment.NetworkSegment.id))
    # for a unique constraint it's always NULL != NULL --> we filter them out
    query = query.filter(segment.NetworkSegment.physical_network.isnot(None))
    query = query.group_by(
        segment.NetworkSegment.network_id,
        segment.NetworkSegment.network_type,
        segment.NetworkSegment.physical_network
    )
    query = query.having(func.count(segment.NetworkSegment.id) > 1)
I've tested this manually and works fine.

neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/.message: How could we have 2 records with same network_id but different network_type or physical_network? Can you please clarify? Seems just network_id should be enough.

This is quite common with hierarchical portbinding[0]. One could have a network_type VXLAN top-level segment and then a multitude of network_type VLAN segments under it. The table ml2_port_binding_levels (model neutron.plugins.ml2.models.PortBindingLevels) will then contain multiple entries per port binding, each line referencing a different segment.

Having only network_id in this constraint would break hierarchical portbinding. 


[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/kilo/ml2-hierarchical-port-binding.html

In hierarchical port binding, the network has one tunnelled network (VXLAN, geneve, GRE) and multiple VLAN type segments. Each VLAN network will be assigned to a different physical network.

In RPN [1], the segments are VLAN type. Each one is assigned to a different physical network. That is what will segregate the traffic between racks.

Reviewing the code and the current features we have in Neutron, I think this constraint is valid.

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/admin/config-routed-networks.html
Ack, thanks for clarification, I forgot about hierarchical portbinding.

neutron/plugins/ml2/managers.py.message:
Checking now the code, where this method (and "release_dynamic_segment") is called?

To allocate a segment, we have "create_network_segments" L207, that is called when a network is created. This method will call "reserve_provider_segment" L293 and there, we'll call to each driver (vlan, vlxan, etc) to reserve a provider segment. In each type driver we allocate the segments.

I must be wrong but I don't see when we call this method.

Right, I see that cisco, arista and cumulus are calling this API method.

But Neutron testing is not properly checking the DB context.

Anyway, I would recommend you to add this retry decorator in "release_dynamic_segment" too because you'll need eventually to call it.

I think allocate_dynamic_segment() is only called by third party drivers that support hierarchical portbinding (HPB[0]). I know of at least networking-arista[1] using it.

The problem I'm having (and which the bug is about) is occuring when the network is already created (including its provider segment) and the driver needs to create a new network segment for an incoming port binding. If two neutron-server instances try to allocate a segment for the same purpose (same network_id, network_type, physical_network) we might end up with two segments for these parameters which have a different segmentation_id. These duplicate segments can break a lot of stuff (configuring wrong vlans on devices, alternating between vlans depending on db query sort order, configuration errors because of "only one VLAN allowed", stuff like that).

So I (with my "driver-dev" hat on) need a way to dynamically allocate and release segments for existing networks without duplicates. allocate_dynamic_segment() tries to do that, but might fail due to the race condition addressed in this patch.

Regarding create_network_segments() I think it will suffer the same problem. Although I'm not yet sure how I'd use it to create a segment for a specific physical_network (or if it's even possible) - if it could be used in such a way we would also have two calls to it trying to allocate the same segment, getting different segmentation_ids from the TypeDriver and then allocate a segment with this data. The VlanTypeDriver cannot help us as it does not know for which segment it is currently allocation an vlan_id. That's why I propose the unique constraint for the networksegments table.

In the networking-arista case[1] mentioned at the beginning they use oslo.lock to guarantee that only one process at a time can create a segment. This does not help if the neutron-server instances are run on different hosts (e.g. kubernetes pods) and can't synchronize via a shared filesystem lock.

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/kilo/ml2-hierarchical-port-binding.html
[1] https://opendev.org/x/networking-arista/src/commit/1327851e5a923a169090d75374e28c00839a854e/networking_arista/ml2/mechanism_arista.py#L358-L361
(no action) I was going to say that "add_network_segment" has its own writer_context, but you are right on wrapping all this section together.
You'll need to add a write context here too.
better use retry_if_session_inactive as this could be used inside active transaction and retry_db_errors will cause misleading error trace

/COMMIT_MSG.message: now that you enable both by default, this headline doesn't reflect the effect. It suggests new tuning knobs are introduced but now that they will be in effect by default.
s/but now/but not
Indeed, lemme change it.

I would probably add some info (maybe in a release note?) explaining what's the impact of each option.

IIUC:

router_always_learn_from_arp_request -> by setting this to False we'll avoid learning from ARP replies observed in the network. Only ARP requests sent by OVN will generate a MAC_Binding entry. For large broadcasts domains, this will avoid learning a large number of MAC addresses that are likely never going to be used by the overlay; hence reducing the size of the SB database and the churn.


dynamic_neigh_routers -> by setting this to True, we avoid pre-populating flows for router to router communication, hence reducing the number of logical flows (and SB database size) and the openflows installed on each hypervisor. This will have a great impact in the OpenStack case where tenants typically connect their routers to the provider network and we'll save a lot of flows. On demand, OVN will ARP router ports as needed and learn their MAC addresses through the MAC_Binding mechanism.
In the worst case scenario where all routers need to talk to all routers, we'd end up with the same case and we'll have as many MAC_Binding entries as LFlows we had when this option is set to False.
reducing

heat/engine/resources/openstack/nova/ser.message: Shouldn't we specify a schema for this Map?

Though currently only {"max_server_per_host": <number>} is supported, the rule 'values' can be any type for a policy i.e numbers, booleans etc.

Also, replacement of a CREATE_FAILED is not that expensive:), wdyt?

> Though currently only {"max_server_per_host": <number>} is supported, the rule 'values' can be any type for a policy i.e numbers, booleans etc.

The schema for a Map allow us to define different types for each key (unlike List), so I don't think that's an obstacle. The downside of having a schema I guess is that as new rules are added they have to be explicitly added to the schema before anyone can use them.

FWIW there's an `ANY` type now: https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/src/branch/master/heat/engine/constraints.py#L86

> Also, replacement of a CREATE_FAILED is not that expensive:), wdyt?

I don't care that much, but any time we're typing instructions about allowed values into the help string instead in machine-readable format (that also produces nice docs!), that seems... suboptimal.
If more rules are added here in the future it will quickly become unwieldy to describe all their constraints in the description of the map.

> The schema for a Map allow us to define different types for each key (unlike List), so I don't think that's an obstacle

The rule keys we add here won't be valid for all types of policies. The only rule that's available atm is valid for 'anti-affinity' rule. Unless we add a bunch of validations we would always be depending on nova validations.

The right way is to consolidated the AVC by ignoring the MCS level of the scontext and tcontext.
As said, sealert and, more generally, setroubleshoot, aren't really "container-friendly".
For instance, a 3.7k AVC file ends being just 2 distinct AVC once we remove the MCS. No need to say sealert will be much faster against that consolidated file.

I have a script for that. Just freshly baked out of some perl factory :). So if we could consider this as a better solution than enforcing some timeout in sealert, that would be really good.

And using setroubleshoot-server would help, but we'll end with an endless file pushing multiple times the same data due to the lack of MCS distinction.

In the meantime, we might merge this current timeout thing, but we shouldn't sit on it and move to other topics... There's a real issue.

roles/collect_logs/files/consolidate-avc.message:
ok so i don't know anything about perl but i can just about read that
it seems neat and all

but mainly the concern is 'why perl'? that is not a comment about perl vs anything else, more like 'we don't have any other perl in our repos' ... so i have a concern about maintainability.

Is there really a huge technical advantage in having this in perl vs bash? Perhaps this is an ignorant statement forgive me but "I (for one ;)) cannot possibly imagine anything going wrong if you try to have this as a bash script"  ;)

Perl is better when it comes to parsing... Bash would be terrible, basically calling sed/awk/grep/others in a way that would just explode. Python might be ok, but it's nothing compared to perl for regexp. And that one is pretty easy, in addition.
So, basically, "use the right tool for the right task" - I won't use a screwdriver for a nail.

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Does Manjaro use all the exact same package names as Arch? I suggest also adding at least a test_manjaro_implies_pacman test definition based on the existing test_arch_implies_pacman one, so that we avoid regressions later. Copy the /etc/os-release from a recent Manjaro installation to bindep/tests/fixtures/manjaro/etc/os-release and have the new test use that so we make sure it's parsed correctly.

Yes it does: https://manjaro.org/features/fresh-and-stable/

Manjaro uses separate mirrors that tack on a few additional Manjaro-specific packages that are not found in the upstream Arch repositories, but the package names are consistent for the packages that they inherit from upstream Arch. They just perform additional testing to make sure the inherited Arch packages are stable before releasing them to Manjaro users.

I will add the testing your referenced and submit another commit. Thank you for your timely and helpful response.

nit: we usually use parentheses instead of line breaks

I think this approach is better than as it would avoid MAC_Bindings entirely. Two things tho:

1) I checked the logs and currently it's failing for SSL connections, we should account for that.

2) Have we tested running this command with a large OVSDB ? My fear is whether this will create a IDL underneath when connecting to the database cuz, if the DB is huge this command can be very slow and could hang for longer periods of time.

Other than that it looks very good! If 2) is not a problem I think we should go with this approach.

Hey Sean,

I am on the Technical Steering Committee for the OpenStack StarlingX project.
StarlingX makes use of airship/armada for management of applications (like openstack) with multiple helm charts.
And StarlingX has made contributions to airship/armada in the past.

I wanted to ping you about the recent activity in airship/armada for support of helmv3 .
https://review.opendev.org/q/owner:seaneagan%2540microsoft.com

A couple of questions:
•	how stable is the support for helmv3 in armada master branch right now ?
•	is there a way to use/configure armada in a backwards configurable mode where it supports helmv2 or even helmv2-or-helmv3 ?
       o	i.e. we were just about to push a fix upstream to armada
       o	but when testing the fix, nothing worked … guessing because all our helm charts are v2
•	 
•	last question … just curious why the recent activity to support helmv3 in armada ?
       o	i.e. I thought the airship direction was to start using flux ?

thanks in advance for info,
Greg Waines (StarlingX Technical Steering Committee)

Hey Greg,

This effort was about migrating Airship 1 to Helm 3 for those deployments which are not able to move to Airship 2, which is now complete and being used against a large set of charts/releases successfully internally. Airship 2 was already using Flux 2 and its helm-controller which supports Helm 3. Please see our recent mailing list message and let us know if there is anything we can do to help:

http://lists.airshipit.org/pipermail/airship-discuss/2021-October/001357.html

so v1 ring will also get dev_id_bytes key; but will ignore it

What do we mean by "v1 ring"? The way I've been thinking about it,

* RingData has no version -- it's just a data structure that can change and evolve over time. I guess if I *had* to put a version on it, it's whatever the Swift version is that you're currently running.
* *.ring.gz files have versions for different serialization formats. Not all formats are capable of storing all data that might be hanging off a RingData.

So yeah, the RingData.to_dict() result has a dev_id_bytes key, but no v1 ring.gz file will, since we don't copy it to _text.
v2 never gets a byteorder key, and always writes/reads the same way regardless of platform
IMHO, it was a bug that we ever wrote it down in a platform-dependent manner -- but by the time we noticed it, it was too late to do anything other than write down which order we used.
a Q is like 8 bytes, so our max len here is 2 ** 64 - which is huge - so that should be enough for all the metadata we want to write.

From a comment I left on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/803665 while thinking about a 32-bit length here:

> As for the possibility of <JSON length> overflowing 32 bits, it looks like each dev in my saio adds ~170 bytes to the JSON metadata -- let's round it up to 200 to accommodate IPv6 (and for rounder numbers). Leaving some space for non-devs metadata, let's say we've got ~4B bytes to play with -- so we'd expect to be able to handle ~20M devices. I think we'll need to rethink a lot of things before we get close to that limit.
> 
> OTOH, I could see an argument that it'd be nice to standardize on 64-bit lengths so we can continue parsing in the face of unrecognized types. Though presumably we'd want to order data in the ring by type code, so encountering an unknown type would be an indication that you can just halt parsing since there's nothing left you understand.

I went with the "64-bit length everywhere" idea because those extra four bytes are nothing compared to the size of even pretty tiny rings.
assignments is like the "number of parts" in row summed up, so you can skip the whole table, but not a single row

I understand that we pull off the magic and then the version which are the first 6 bytes. But when contrasting serialize_vX and deserialize_vX they aren't really the opposite of each other. The serialize code does all the serialization where as deserialise does only deserializes after the 6 bytes.. just doesn't feel properly symmetric.

If we take https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/811833 as it currenlty stands, we actually need to replica_count in the metdata. So we have 2 options. We can just add it to serialize_v2 as a float (just because that makes more sense) or we can just calculate it here, something like:

  data_len, = struct.unpack('!Q', gz_file.read(8))
  ring_dict['replica_count'] = float(data_len // max_row_length + float(data_len % max_row_length) / max_row_length)
  if metadata_only:
      return ring_dict

   with FixedLengthReader(gz_file, data_len) as data:
       ...

 I guess option 1 is the easiest, it's only a single float so doesn't cost much.. but we could calulate the result and not take up any extra space (option 2).

Not really, not without doing it ourselves. I could imagine doing something fairly clever during serialization/deserialization to drop that leading b'\x00' from each dev, but I really don't have the stomach to roll my own array().

Let's just let gzip do something smart instead.

you did mention in a chat that we could use the first bit for something like a sticky bit or we could use it for marking a device as enabled or not. That come up in an SRE meeting at work (I think from Clay), to be able to mark a device as disabled so it's still there but things (like proxies) know if it should go look elsewhere rather then relying entirely on error limited nodes.

However, it'll be some extra code to maintain, but should just be something like:
 # map just the first bit: ie 1000
 enabled = <dev_id from ring> | (1 << (dev_length - 1))
 # All 1's then bitshift so it starts with a 0, ie 0111
 dev_bitmap = (1 << dev_length) -1 >> 1
 dev_id = <dev_if from ring> & dev_bitmap

NOTE: I might have over thought it a little :P
though wouldn't in both cases, sticky or enabled eaiser just to put something in the devices dicts.
py27 array.array() doesn't qupport 'Q' -- struct does, though!

devstack/plugin.sh.message:
If I am understanding this correctly, there are two aspects to consider:

1. Branched devstack (stable/* branches) would install setuptools from master. We would need to update this code we branch for an upcoming GA release.

2. "pip will not upgrade it and will not break it": not sure this is how it goes. Devstack installs setuptools via pip [1] matching version in upper-constraints.txt [2]. So, setuptools is upgraded and pip fails to clean up te directory from the RPM as you mentioned above. The reason why this patch works around the issue is because it re-installs setuptools from RPM *after* after pip installs setuptools (i.e. RPM install -> pip install -> RPM install). This means we end up having two setuptools installed and most likely with mismatched versions:

  $ rpm -q python3-setuptools
  python3-setuptools-50.3.2-1.el8.noarch
  $ python3 -c "import sys; import setuptools; print(setuptools.version.__version__)"
  53.0.0

[1] https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/556f84aea90c572873fc9834292635b41e590224/tools/install_pip.sh#L153-L155
[2] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/fead914306d23aae6e149f3f75dbf19f563bb83d/upper-constraints.txt#L587

I'm not sure if we should add "shared" field to the SGs really as this may be confusing for users because of the "shared" field in the network object which means something slightly different in fact.
I know that we should allow to filter SGs to get only those which are shared with the tenant so passing "shared" attribute in the request is IMO fine but returning it in the SG object isn't really necessary IMHO.
I'm giving -1 just for visibility. But if others have completly different opinion about it, I can change my vote 😊

Hi Slawek, I think the network's "shared" field means the same thing as SG's in the response. Both of them mean if the resource is shared with the tenant via RBAC. The only difference though is network allows users to create/set a "shared" network which means shared to all tenants. (Create a rbac policy for tenant '*'). We don't support that for SGs yet. But no matter either the SG/network is shared with all or specific tenants, the "shared" field in response only tells if the resource is shared with the current tenant.  https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/065e4b1705616198dee648892d730ba9652980a5/neutron/objects/rbac_db.py#L54-L63

Also, I see some other resources that support RBAC also have the shared field in the response, like subnetpools, address_scopes, etc. From a user's point of view, knowing either the resource returned from API is shared or owned is useful because users usually have limited operation permission on the shared resources. For example, security group list currently returns both shared and owned SGs for a tenant. But the tenant won't be able to modify the shared security group. Without showing the shared field to users, this restriction can be confusing.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
I was wondering if it would be easier to check the lock at this part instead on the do_sync(). That way we wouldn't potentially need a lock for the SB DB (as per my comment) neither it would affect manually running the ovn-db-sync script.

For example:

self._nb_ovn.idl.set_lock('ovn_db_inconsistencies_periodics')
if self._nb_ovn.idl.has_lock:
    self.nb_synchronizer = ...
    ...

self._maintenance_thread = maintenance.MaintenanceThread()
...

Could be a possibility (only for the NB sync, not the SB sync).

But I prefer the "nb_synchronizer.sync()" method to check the lock inside, as is now (just a personal preference, the "OvnNbSynchronizer" should be aware of this lock).

Yeah I am indifferent, I thought here it would be simpler as we won't need to account for that has_lock/is_lock_contended in the script itself. Just when running within the service because that's when you could have multiple instances calling this method.
Unnecessary: the idl has a configured lock, you created it in the previous line.

I agree that the issue reported is a problem in "MaintenanceWorker".

I have two concerns here. As commented in the LP bug, "MaintenanceWorker" execute two different operations:
1) the sync between the Neutron DB and the OVN DB, done by "OvnNbSynchronizer"
2) the inconsistencies repair, executed by "DBInconsistenciesPeriodics"

Both classes, executed in parallel, use the same IDL instance with the same lock. My concern here is that because a "DBInconsistenciesPeriodics" task is being executed, no other server could execute the "OvnNbSynchronizer" tasks.

The "DBInconsistenciesPeriodics" are executed periodically, that means if we skip one execution, we'll try again. But that doesn't happen with "OvnNbSynchronizer" tasks (from L102 to L106). If no server has the lock to execute the sync methods, we'll never execute them.

I would like Terry and Lucas to take a look at this patch and check if what I'm saying is correct.

We also call this method when running the ovn-db-sync script manually, did we check it to make sure that this lock check does not affect it ? 

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/603951809a45797697135e03eb4870c094371480/neutron/cmd/ovn/neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py#L235-L242

Right, so using has_lock here is a problem because when running the script manually won't work because the IDL from ovn-db-sync script hasn't created a lock. Indeed we should check for is_lock_contended here or a combination of the two to account for the manual usage of the script as well

If there is not lock defined or it was removed, "Idl.hash_lock" is False.

The problem here is that you should check idl.is_lock_contended. There is a difference between idl.has_lock and idl.is_lock_contended [1]. This is what "DBInconsistenciesPeriodics" checks [2]


[1]https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/d2e97030eda5dfafc875ec056788c49e2570d2ef/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L169-L170
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/3cae410b3094e74549a1941e0b7d833229ae51d5/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/maintenance.py#L195-L197
Q: Do we also need a lock for SB DB here ?

We don't create a lock for the SB idl in the "DBInconsistenciesPeriodics" class.

However, as in NB DB, there is no need to execute those commands from all servers. I think that is out of scope from this patch but something that we should implement.
Yeah DBInconsistenciesPeriodics doesn't touch the south database, but this does. That's why I think we should guard it too.

I don't think this has any effect ? This is the end of the method scope after the greenthread has already been spawned.

Also I am not sure about this is_lock_contended, from what I understood this will return False when we do not ask for any locks (and we do not create a lock when running the script manually).

That's why I thought that doing such checks on post_fork_initialize() is better cause we only care about locks at that point not for the manual case.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
We have some concerns about the neutron_pg_drop and I filed an RFE [0] to allow configure the default policy and be able to remove such port group. The concern is mainly that on large clusters, this port group have so many ports that every change (add/delete) involves ovsdb-server sending a *large* update message with all the port UUIDs being expensive to send (ASCII).

Another enhancement in flight is to add support for 'update3' method in OVS python lib which Terry's working on.

The approach I used when I first implemented the same functionality that you're doing now is to use one port group per subnet which would mitigate the problem I just described but makes maintenance and synchronization a bit more complicated (eg. 1:1 mapping between subnet and PG, adding external_ids, db sync code, maintenance task, ...).

[0] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1947807

I'm not a big fan of such configuration knobs. It looks odd to remove the neutron-pg-drop and then introduce a new large PG :) 
If Terry believes that 'update3' support in OVS Py lib will fix this, I'm totally fine with this approach as, like you say, it's simple (and neat 😊

CC'Terry :)
For now IMO we can go with that one as code is simpler. Maybe we can make it configurable in the feature to make possible turning it off in large scale deployments if that will cause troubles. Wdyt?
double worded
Done

Just a food for thoughts - we may want to set a default behavior for ACLs when not matched - meaning OVN could start dropping packets and ACLs will be whitelisting because of scale issues with neutron_pg_drop. With the approach in this patch and if OVN implements the functionality we need, we will still remain with one huge PG that will be needed. I don't have a solution for it, just thinking out loud :)
Than we can go with other approach proposed by Daniel and add such "allow_dhcp_pg" per subnet maybe. But for now I'm not sure if that is really needed.

The only problem I saw with the large port group was that when using active/passive replication, it doesn't even use uodate2 and transmits the whole row with an update message. There is an RFE to fix that. In general the client already uses mutate operations when communicating with ovsdb-server and gets update2 notification back. Update3 is just aodification to the update2 we already use that allows snapshots on reconnects.

There is probably some overhead when generating the "old" row for a notification in the oython-ovs library itself, but nothing going over the wire there.

Kuba's concern is the same one I showed in a previous review on this patch. Not so long time ago I opened an RFE like:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1947807

I expect this to be implemented soon and then we're going to end up with another big port group... 

I already implemented back then the subnet approach, then reverted and we can put it back if needed as I think it'd scale a bit better:

https://github.com/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/d5a0de261507192b61f2cdf80a537ceaa0792dc3

Shall we consider bringing this code back?

Also, @Terry, do you see any improvement with the 'update3' support that you're trying to add to the OVS Python library?

I think it would be safer to always include the keys in external_ids and an empty string (for cases where it's not present). Otherwise we can get some weird behaviors when it comes to updates, for example:

1. Port had a dns_name set to it
2. We then wrote that dns_name to the external_ids in OVN NBDB
3. Port gets an update that deletes the dns_name
4. Now, port.get('dns_name') will return None and the old dns_name won't be deleted from OVN NBDB

This could lead to old values being still present in the OVN NBDB.

I would change this to:

external_ids = {...
    ovn_const.OVN_DNS_NAME_EXT_ID_KEY: port.get('dns_name', ''),
    ovn_const.OVN_QOS_POLICY_EXT_ID_KEY: port.get('qos_policy_id', '')

I don't know what would lead A and B to being sequenced again, but I know that the algorithm allows for it and the software as written now would support it.  I think it could have happened in the past before global repo state was implemented.  And I don't want to prevent it from happening again in the future.  In short, I have no concrete current case for it, but I think it's important for us to allow it.

I don't think we can re-use the same buildset.  The first time through, the jobs may have run to completion.  The second time through they may also run to completion.  We would have database entries with a single buildset with duplicate "final" jobs, which is not something we intend to support.  It makes much more sense for those to be different buildsets.

Why do we need to do this?  Why can't we continue using the current random buildset UUID?  We already re-set it at the appropriate times.

I think there may be a fundamental problem with this: nothing in NNFI assumes that we can't recreate a queue sequence a second time.  That used to happen quite frequently in Zuul.  Fixing the job graph at global buildset creation time has greatly reduced the opportunity for that, but I don't want to assume that doing something like running a promote on the item at the top of the queue won't still be able to do it.  Or we might even write a "restart builds" command.

To elaborate/clarify: imagine we have A<-B in the queue.  We create buildests #1 and #2 respectively.  A fails, so we have A as a severed head, and B as the next head.  B gets buildset #3 created for it.  Then something happens and A<-B are sequenced again.  We should get buildset #4 for B; we should not re-use buildset #2.

What would be the event that leads to A and B being sequenced again? Wouldn't this only be possible in case there is another item X ahead of A and B that failed? In that case we'd get a different buildset UUID because the buildsets ahead have changed.

Regarding the "why", please see my response below.

Sorry, I think I did not fully understand what you mean by "sequenced again". In the case of a "restart builds" command I think it should be fine to keep the same buildset. We could just restart the builds as the position in the queue did not change and everything else should be still valid.

I'll look into that test so I understand more of what's going on.  But maybe if we need something like this we could explicitly list the items in the buildset, so we can invalidate it that way.  So the item ahead sequence would be one reason to invalidate a buildset (but perhaps not the only one, and we wouldn't assume that every item ahead sequence maps 1:1 to a buildset).

Yes, there is as little logic as possible in the re-enqueue method.  The idea behind the NNFI method is that it converges on the correct state.  If any conditions are different compared to the current state, then the method corrects the state to match the current conditions, and this includes creating new buildsets if needed.  The re-enqueue method should definitely not re-implement the NNFI algorithm.  It should just get the item into the queue and then the scheduler should always process the pipeline after that is complete in order to perform corrective action.

I'd be totally fine with the re-enqueue doing only what's necessary, but I think there are currently cases where the buildset of an item is still used and NOT reset by the pipeline manager later on. E.g. see the failing test case test_live_reconfiguration_shared_queue_removed.

I'm fine with arguing that the items ahead/behind pointers will eventually converge to the correct state and that they might be wrong after a re-enqueue. However, in the mentioned test the old buildset was still used and not reset even though the items ahead moved to a different queue.

Maybe there is a different way to fix this, but I think some information about the previous order of the items is lost during re-enqueue and the deterministic buildset UUID allows us to detect such ordering changes.

tests/unit/test_scheduler.py.message: Assert that we are not referencing any items outside our own change queue.

I think this is the crux: the intention is that after reconfiguring, we must run NNFI to fix up the queues.

A key thing to remember is that a Zuul ChangeQueue is simultaneously a queue and a tree.  The queue is the strict linear ordering of changes which is relatively fixed.  The tree is ephemeral and can change every time a job completes.

When we re-enqueue, we put all the items into either the same or new queues in that strict linear order, then we let NNFI fix up the tree as necessary.  ChangeQueue.queue is the linear queue, QueueItem.item_ahead is the tree.

I pushed up a followup change for discussion which allows the pipeline processor to run and I think shows that the right thing is happening with the buildsets.

I'm aware that the pipeline manager corrects the ahead/behind pointers as mentioned in the commit message.

The thing for me is that the ahead/behind pointers are referencing items OUTSIDE the current queue after the re-enqueue. I mean yes, it is corrected by the pipeline manager but this seems a little too loose to me and the correct behavior feels like a lucky side-effect.

If that is the intended behavior we might want to add a comment to the reEnqueueItem() method that explains this. Still, I hope that we don't have any other cases that the pipeline manager can't detect correctly that are not covered with a test case.

The deterministic buildset UUID was just an attempt to tie the buildset UUID more to the position of the item in the queue, which would allow us to detect an outdated buildset. But I also agree that it might have some other issues that I did not anticipate.

I'm also thinking if this can be a problem when we have the pipeline state in Zookeeper and an item is removed during re-enqueue but still referenced via another item's ahead/behind.

Maybe something we then have to account for when restoring the pipeline state.

validations_libs/validation_actions.py.message:
What about the group which is not accessed at all here.

We should add the group in the self instance:

      self.group = group

And use the per-instance attribute self.group everywhere like we do for self.validation_path.

BUT, that will break the API. Then if we don't want to do that, it's better to remove the 'group' argument from the constructor method, because it is pretty useless.

Or we can make one small, self contained, change here. And resolve the issue of group parameter during the tech checkpoint.

There is no reason why we can't adjust the methods to accept the `group` param and defer to instance attribute value if it is `None`.
